questions.question: 1. Which matrix is commonly used for implementing perspective projection in computer graphics?
questions.explanation: The perspective matrix is commonly used to implement perspective projection in computer graphics, transforming 3D coordinates into 2D space.

questions.question: 2. What role does the 'near' and 'far' planes play in the context of camera frustum?

answers.a: They define the material properties of objects in the scene.
answers.b: They control the visibility of objects based on their distance from the camera.
answers.c: They determine the focal length of the camera lens.
answers.d: They influence the lighting conditions in the rendered image.

questions.explanation: The 'near' and 'far' planes in the camera frustum control the visibility of objects based on their distance from the camera, ensuring accurate rendering of scenes.

questions.question: 3. What is the purpose of the view matrix in computer graphics?

answers.a: To define the position and orientation of the virtual camera.
answers.b: To transform object coordinates from model space to world space.
answers.c: To apply shading algorithms to the rendered image.
answers.d: To store pixel values of an image.

questions.explanation: The view matrix is used to define the position and orientation of the virtual camera, allowing for proper visualization of the 3D scene.

questions.question: 4. How does a depth buffer contribute to the realism of rendered scenes?

answers.a: It controls the saturation levels of colors in the rendered image.
answers.b: It manages the transparency of objects in the scene.
answers.c: It simulates the effects of atmospheric perspective by assigning depth values to pixels.
answers.d: It determines the overall brightness of the rendered image.

questions.explanation: A depth buffer assigns depth values to pixels, simulating atmospheric perspective in rendered scenes, enhancing realism by portraying objects farther away with reduced visibility.

questions.question: 5. In computer graphics, what is the purpose of the 'aspect ratio' in relation to cameras?

answers.a: It determines the intensity of specular reflection on surfaces.
answers.b: It defines the proportion of width to height in the rendered image.
answers.c: It controls the field of view of the camera.
answers.d: It adjusts the level of ambient lighting in the scene.

questions.explanation: The 'aspect ratio' in computer graphics defines the proportion of width to height in the rendered image, ensuring proper scaling and visual representation.
